posts.name: agithubuser
posts.cooked:
(I was asked to move the discussion about what I percieve to be a bug from Remove the need for a mobile phone · Issue #1757 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub to this forum, so this is what I am doing.)

Actual result: The user is forced to use a mobile phone, making metadata-based surveillance easier since the user’s mobile phone number is then associated with Signal
Expected result: It is possible to securely communicate without linking one’s mobile phone to Signal usage

Relevance:

“We kill people based on metadata.”

General Michael Hayden, former director of the NSA and the CIA

Source:

The New York Review of Books

'We Kill People Based on Metadata' | David Cole

A bill to rein in NSA spying on Americans’ metadata has wide bipartisan support in Congress. It is an important first step, but it addresses only one part of the NSA’s vast surveillance activities.

Additional relevance:

On October 4, 2016, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and Open Whisper Systems published a series of documents revealing that OWS had received a subpoena requiring them to provide information associated with two phone numbers for a federal grand jury investigation in the first half of 2016.[41][42][43] Only one of the two phone numbers was registered on Signal, and because of how the service is designed, OWS was only able to provide “the time the user’s account had been created and the last time it had connected to the service”.[42][41]

Source: Signal (software) - Wikipedia (references to original sources therein)

As mentioned in the bug report, I will respect any decision made by the project but I’d highly appreciate if the rationale for the decision would be made public. Thanks.

posts.cooked:
Registering with an email address Feature Requests
Moxie wrote at least two times that this is on the roadmap: I don’t think it would be too difficult to implement, the tricky part is the usability. I’d also like a word on this from @moxie0, the last comment I linked is two years old after all.

posts.name: Cortana's zur
posts.cooked: It’s definitely possible. You see all these new chat clients using the protocol without a phone number. In the beginning, the software was about secure sms. It’s evolved into a secure messaging suite.

posts.name: Mat
posts.cooked:
The problem, and not at all a trivial one to solve, is the unique user-name management.

User-names that are some identifier with secondary, unique-by-design role (phone number, e-mail address) ensure the system needs no functionality to ensure uniqueness, but leaks potentially dangerous communication meta-data and thus defy the very purpose of a secure communication system. In addition this makes the system operator with increased frequency a coerced accomplice to the client’s adversary (as mentioned above).

There is no simple way for one isolated communication system to solve this problem.

My preference would be for the user to generate a private-public key-pair, and submit the public key to the system operator. The public key is the user identifier. The server stores all messages received from sender clients, keeps them until the recipient client sends a signed retrieval request (or some reasonable maximum time…). The client sends his public key to his correspondents using a secure channel.

This would provide an extremely secure communication protocol. It would, however, have a few usability problems - easy to solve for some, quite difficult for others. Most notable among those are the conveyance of public key to the correspondents, public key verification and public key chaining/replacement - which could be solved by the server operator, at the cost of some security weakening. These could be accepted opted-in) or not accepted by an individual user, based on his threat model. The main thing however is that employing those usability enhancing/meta-data leaking features would be optional. (Or, at the very least, opting-out of them would be simple and without impacting the fundamental functionality).

I am looking for an iMessage alternate because of the following use case:

Girlfriend will be traveling abroad and only taking her Windows laptop. She has no phone, & no iPod.

We want to be able to do everything we currently do with our Mac laptops; iMessage & video chat, me on my MacBookPro & iPhone, her on her Windows laptop… but Signal requires a phone number an she doesn’t have one.

We’ve settled on Jabber for text only communication but it’s not ideal.

posts.name: Trolldemorted
posts.cooked:
Where do you live? A prepaid-SIM card in germany costs about 5€, and you can also use landline phone numbers for signal’s registration.

Use signal-cli, Signal-Windows or Signal-Desktop as the master device and you should be good to go.

Y34RZ3R0:

Girlfriend will be traveling abroad and only taking her Windows laptop. She has no phone, & no iPod.

You can try Wire. It seems to have an ok encryption and okish privacy policy. Afaik it should work without a phone.
Or Skype - no end to end encryption, most likely problems with the privacy policy.
Wire is working for us now, thank you.

posts.name: Jay Patel
posts.cooked: You can have signal installed as stand alone and once verified no need to use phone number… Also you can get phone number using Google voice Voice

So far the policy is: No smartphone, no user, if I got that correctly… This sounds strange to me for a program/app that tries to attract people, who are concerned about data security.
I had high hopes in Signal, and when I found out that I had to register a telephone, I was a bit shocked. Even though Matiasig tried to explain it properly (even to tech-idiots like me), I still don’t understand, why it’s not possible (15 years after I used ICQ for the first time) to have a standalone-desktop-version with a user-defined identifier.

Spanus:

I still don’t understand, why it’s not possible (15 years after I used ICQ for the first time) to have a standalone-desktop-version with a user-defined identifier.

It is possible, it’s just not implemented.

posts.name: Trolldemorted
posts.cooked: Signal-Windows and Signal-Desktop can be used on PCs without a smartphone.

link_counts.title: GitHub - signal-csharp/Signal-Windows: Signal Private Messenger for Windows

posts.name: Quentin
posts.cooked: Hmm… you still need a smartphone to scan the QR Code for a new install…

posts.name: Trolldemorted
posts.cooked: New installs do not require any QR code scans and thus no smartphone.

posts.name: Quentin
posts.cooked: According to the doc, and according to what I see when I lauch the desktop app (https://support.signal.org/hc/en-us/articles/214507138-How-do-I-install-Signal-Desktop-), you still need to install on your smartphone first

link_counts.title: How do I install Signal Desktop? – Support

posts.name: Trolldemorted
posts.cooked: Signal-Desktops contribution guidelines cover standalone registration, and Signal-Windows can do it out-of-the-box.

Just adding my two cents… I think that the simplicity of avoiding the creation of yet another unique ID is one of the key selling points for this app as I convert people away from Hangouts and replace their SMS apps with it. The fact the desktop app needs to link will likely not affect people that much save for serious users.

posts.name: O
posts.cooked:
But the only ‘meta data’ OWS were able to hand over is how old the account was and where in the world the device last connected to their servers.

If that amount of information is a big concern for you then I highly suggest upgrading to a Nokia 3310 or something
These people are apologists, your concern is valid. Use Wickr.

posts.name: Dan Lenski
posts.cooked:
Matiasig:

This would provide an extremely secure communication protocol. It would, however, have a few usability problems - easy to solve for some, quite difficult for others. Most notable among those are the conveyance of public key to the correspondents, public key verification and public key chaining/replacement - which could be solved by the server operator, at the cost of some security weakening. These could be accepted opted-in) or not accepted by an individual user, based on his threat model. The main thing however is that employing those usability enhancing/meta-data leaking features would be optional. (Or, at the very least, opting-out of them would be simple and without impacting the fundamental functionality).

Congratulations. You’ve just reinvented the PGP key distribution model
